Ye Dryads, who woo the recess</br>Where the oak's ample shadow extends,</br>To your haunts of retirement I press,</br>And the Muse my intrusion attends.</br>From the morning too brilliant I stray,</br>From the solar meridian blaze,</br>When mute is the chorister's lay,</br>And the sun darts his vertical rays.

Retirement, how sweet is thy power!</br>I fly from the indolent breeze;</br>I fly from the hot-parching hour;</br>Receive me, ye gloom-shedding trees.</br>With you, lonely Silence prevails,</br>You shelter my Celadon's seat,</br>Whose cot no ambition assails,</br>Save that to be honest and neat.

No sycophants here shall be heard,</br>Where Friendship her quietude seeks,</br>Sincerity utters the word,</br>From the lips of Veracity speaks.</br>What though in this temperate scite,</br>This hermitage hidden and mean,</br>No pane of high polish the light</br>Reflects to illumine the scene;

What though, on the unadorn'd wall</br>Does Sculpture her chissel deny,</br>No portal conduct to the hall,</br>Where paintings replenish the eye;</br>Yet here, in profusion of sweets,</br>Calm Solitude leads by the hand</br>The hind, who felicity meets,</br>And scorns the least wish to be grand.

The gay fascination of wealth</br>No envy to Celadon brings;</br>Be his but contentment and health,</br>With pity he looks down on kings.</br>Exempt from vexation and strife,</br>Devotion pours balm on his breast;</br>How smooth is that tenor of life,</br>Where conscience spreads poppies of rest!

Though lost are the posies of spring,</br>Their beauties all gone to decay,</br>Runcina the lily shall bring,</br>As soft and as sweet as the May.</br>How delicate white are her flowers!</br>How grateful and cool to the sight!</br>In silver-like grandeur she towers,</br>The garden's first pride and delight.

The amaranth has not denied</br>The eglantine's blossom to join;</br>The currant I see by her side,</br>At the foot of the wide-spreading vine.</br>The boughs of the cherry and pear</br>A canopy mutually form,</br>His cottage from perils to spare,</br>When rises the war of the storm.

And now, clouds collecting behold,</br>Whose darkness conceals the sun's light,</br>Though noon, yet what horrors unfold!</br>—appears an unseasonable night!</br>The thunder, impressive of pain,</br>Rolls awfully solemn around;</br>And now it reverb'rates again;</br>Tremendous indeed is the sound.

How dark and how dismal the scene!</br>Now rushes in torrents the rain;</br>Red flashes of Fate intervene;</br>Now shakes with convulsions the plain.</br>Let elements fretful contend,</br>The aether dissolve in a blaze;</br>To the breast of my unappall'd friend</br>Their fury no tremor conveys.

The terrible concert is o'er,</br>Hush'd all its impetuous rage.</br>Great Ruler!  to Thee let me pour</br>The thanks which my bosom engage.</br>The tempest is o'er, and the Sun</br>Descends with his Thetis to rest.</br>If e'er by my theme thou wert won,</br>Come, Delia, sole queen of my breast.

Lo, Evening, mild daughter of Day,</br>In aspect as thou most serene;</br>Her smiles shall enliven my lay,</br>So calm and unclouded her mien.</br>The lark to her nestlings descends,</br>The wood deepens faster to brown;</br>To the village the cottager bends,</br>And lays him contentedly down.

The flocks and the herds are at large,</br>Their coverts of coolness they leave,</br>To taste of the rill's blady marge,</br>And share the soft gifts of the eve.</br>The swallow, in search of his prey,</br>Skims lightly o'er thistle and brake;</br>Glides swift as for plunder or prey,</br>His wings dash the wave of the lake.

How bright are the smiles of the youth,</br>Where summer perpetually reigns,</br>Thou gem of original truth,</br>Shall we join in the dance on the plains?</br>Thro' the fields where the purple-ey'd tare</br>Blooms lavish thy presence to greet:</br>To the glade of refreshment repair,</br>Where offers the moss-cushion'd seat.

To gain a repast for the eye,</br>Yon eminence shall we explore;</br>There, Delia, together descry</br>The streamers that crimson the shore;</br>Till the view by gradation shall fade,</br>The evening's late shadows prevail,</br>And Cynthia soft mantle the shade,</br>Full-orb'd, tell her marvellous tale?

Bright boast of my pastoral lay,</br>Dear maid of my uniform love,</br>Soon the morn of the long summer's day,</br>And its noon, must to evening remove;</br>But soon, when her shadows are fled,</br>The morning the day shall renew;</br>The sun shall arise from his bed,</br>Relumine each beautiful view.

How like is the portrait of man;</br>The morn of his infancy fades,</br>The race of his manhood soon ran,</br>And age bends him down to the shades.</br>But, like the bright morning's return,</br>Regenerate he shall arise,</br>In triumph burst forth from the urn,</br>And beam in the bliss of the skies.</br>
